revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Civic nationalism}} {{Redirect|National liberal||National Liberal Party (disambiguation){{!}}National Liberal Party}} {{Liberalism sidebar|Variants}} '''National liberalism''' is a variant of [[liberalism]], combining liberal policies and issues with elements of [[nationalism]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philosophybasics.com/branch_liberalism.html |title=Liberalism - By Branch / Doctrine - The Basics of Philosophy |website=Philosophybasics.com |date=2008 |author=Luke Mastin |accessdate=2017-07-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Pera|first1=Marcello|title=Why We Should Call Ourselves Christians: The Religious Roots of Free Societies|date=2011|publisher=Encounter Books|isbn=9781594035654|url=https://books.google.it/books?id=rq4hCpCjnlsC&pg=PT15&lpg=PT15&dq=%22national+liberalism%22+variant&source=bl&ots=OyRry7vbSB&sig=ad2Wtt_XooFq3_0YT3Y_afuTh34&hl=it&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiQsqrNv_nTAhXFVRoKHSqwCQg4ChDoAQhjMAc#v=onepage&q=%22national%20liberalism%22&f=false|accessdate=20 July 2017|language=en}}</ref> and/or a term used to describe a series of [[Europe]]an political parties that have been especially active in the 19th century in several national contexts such as [[Central Europe]], the [[Nordic countries]] and [[Southeast Europe]].
==Definitions== National liberalism, whose goals were the pursuit of individual/economic freedom and national sovereignty,<ref>Lothar Gall und Dieter Langewiesche - Liberalismus und Region, München 1995, pp. 4–10.</ref>{{Verification needed|date=May 2017}} refers primarily to an ideology and a movement of the 19th century,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Nilsson|first1=Göran B.|title=The Founder: André Oscar Wallenberg (1816-1886), Swedish Banker, Politician & Journalist|date=2005|publisher=Almqvist & Wiksell International|isbn=9789122021025|page=80|url=https://books.google.it/books?id=mayVK6aHydYC&pg=PA80&lpg=PA80&dq=%22national+liberalism%22+combining+liberalism+nationalism&source=bl&ots=iRJvwEqhdt&sig=H8jMY2mrQFL-Zn_DhMnAmLWGHlA&hl=it&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj6g9XgyvnTAhUKDsAKHcgoB-AQ6AEIVDAG#v=onepage&q=%22national%20liberalism%22&f=false|accessdate=20 July 2017|language=en}}</ref> but national-liberal parties exist also today.
[[József Antall]], a historian and [[Christian democracy|Christian democrat]] who served as the first post-communist [[Prime Minister of Hungary|Prime Minister]] of [[Hungary]], described national liberalism as "part and parcel of the emergence of the nation state" in 19th-century Europe.<ref name="ÖzselReflections">{{cite book|last1=Özsel|first1=Doğancan|title=Reflections on Conservatism|date=2011|publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing|isbn=1443833959|page=255|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uh0rBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA255&lpg=PA255&dq=%22national+liberalism%22++++Antall&source=bl&ots=a21Wz9wqee&sig=WjLCWGwjysWKjKqeE2fRqBqy84A&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjJ_-bEkPPTAhWH3SYKHUOjDuwQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=%22national%20liberalism%22%20%20%20%20Antall&f=false|accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref>
According to Oskar Mulej, "in terms of both ideologies and political party traditions it may be argued that in the [[Central Europe]]an lands a distinct type of liberalism, peculiar to this region evolved through the nineteenth century"<ref name="Mulej">{{cite web|author1=Oskar Mulej|title=NATIONAL LIBERALS AND THEIR PROGENY APPROACHING THE PECULIAR DEVELOPMENTS IN CENTRAL EUROPEAN LIBERAL PARTY TRADITIONS, 1867–1918|url=http://rcin.org.pl/Content/56895/WA303_77550_A295-APH-R-111_Mulej.pdf|website=rcin.org.pl|publisher=Acta Poloniae Historica 111, 2015}}</ref> and citing Maciej Janowski, "the word 'national' acted as more or less synonymous with 'liberal'" ("'national' alone was sufficient to arouse suspicions of liberal associations").<ref>Maciej Janowski, ‘ Wavering Friendship : liberal and national ideas in nineteenth century East-Central Europe’, Ab Imperio , 3–4 (2000), 69–90, 80.</ref> Also according to Mulej, in [[Southeast Europe]] "'national liberals' also played visible if not central roles, but with rather different, region-specific characteristics, which to a considerable extent distinguished them from their Central European counterparts".<ref name="Mulej"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Oskar Mulej |url=http://www.iwm.at/publications/5-junior-visiting-fellows-conferences/vol-xxxiii/national-liberal-heirs-of-the-old-austria |title=National Liberal Heirs of the Old Austria: “Deviations” in Liberal Party Traditions, 1867-1918 | IWM |publisher=Institute for Human Sciences |website=iwm.at |date=2014-05-15 |accessdate=2017-07-20}}</ref>
In his book ''Up From Conservatism,'' [[Michael Lind]] defines "national liberalism" in a way that ''[[The Progressive]]'' describes as matching [[historian]] [[Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr.]]'s use of the expression "[[Vital Center]]".<ref name="HarveyWobbling">{{cite news|last1=Harvey|first1=Kaye|title=Wobbling around the center|url=http://search.proquest.com/news/docview/231946192/fulltextPDF/AF05AF9F5275407APQ/2?accountid=10226|accessdate=16 May 2017|publisher=[[The Progressive]]|date=October 1966}}</ref> Lind himself defines "national liberalism" as uniting "moderate social conservatism with moderate economic liberalism".<ref name="LindUpFrom">{{cite book|last1=Lind|first1=Michael|title=Up from Conservatism|date=2013|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=1476761159|page=32|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FeEeAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA33&dq=%22national+liberalism%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiR0-TmnvTTAhWFRiYKHfbHCf4Q6AEITTAI#v=onepage&q=%22national%20liberalism%22&f=false|accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref>
[[Gordon Smith (academic)|Gordon Smith]], a leading scholar of comparative European politics, understands national liberalism as a political concept that lost popularity when the success of nationalist movements in creating nation states rendered it no longer necessary to specify that a liberal ideal, party or politician was "national".<ref name=SmithLiberalism>"Between Left and Right: The Ambivalence of European Liberalism," pp. 16–28, in ''Liberal Parties in Western Europe,'' Emil J. Kirchner, ed., Cambridge University Press, 1988, {{ISBN|0521323940}}.</ref>
==History== The roots of national liberalism are to be found in the 19th century, when [[conservative liberalism]] and/or [[classical liberalism]] was the ideology of the political classes in most [[Europe]]an countries and in particular those of [[Central Europe]], then governed by hereditary [[monarchy|monarchies]].
At their origin, national liberals, although pro-business, were not necessarily advocates of [[free trade]] and [[economic liberalism]] per se and sometimes favoured cooperation between the government and the national industry, moderate levels of protectionism, the establishment of preferential custom unions, subsidies for infant industry or companies considered of national strategic importance and various forms of industrial planning.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}
National liberalism was popular in a number of countries including [[Germany]], [[Austria]], [[Denmark]], [[Sweden]], [[Finland]] and [[Romania]] during the 19th century.<ref name=Kuunmaki>Kurunmaki, Jussi. “On the Difficulty of Being a National Liberal in Nineteenth-Century Finland.” Contributions to the History of Concepts, vol. 8, no. 2, 2013, pp. 83–95., https://www.jstor.org/stable/43610946.</ref>{{verification needed|date=May 2017}} In Germany, Austria and Romania, national liberals and/or "National Liberal" parties were long in government.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}} More specifically, in [[German language|German-speaking]] countries national liberals were also in favour of a more authoritarian or conservative political regime because of the multi-ethnic character or heterogeneous nature of countries like the [[Austrian Empire]] (later officially renamed [[Austria-Hungary]]) or the newly created Germany under [[Chancellor of Germany|Chancellor]] [[Otto von Bismarck]].{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}
===Germany=== In 19th-century Germany, believers in national liberalism differed from [[civic nationalism|liberal nationalists]] in that they believed in a more authoritarian presence in Europe and a strong [[German Empire]]. Liberal nationalists, such as [[Max Weber]], were looking towards a democratic Germany in cooperation with the other European powers.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
At the time of the German Empire, national liberalism was represented by the [[National Liberal Party (Germany)|National Liberal Party]] (NLP), the largest in the [[Reichstag (German Empire)|Reichstag]] for several years. National Liberals supported Bismarck, who served as Chancellor from 1871 ([[unification of Germany]]) to 1890, until the late 1870s when the Chancellor reversed his early [[free trade]] policies, became a proponent of [[protectionism]], opposed increasing parliamentary powers and ultimately pandered for the support of the [[German Conservative Party]] (largely representing the wealthy landowning elite [[Junker (Prussia)|Junkers]] of [[Prussia]]).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Farmer|first1=Alan|title=My Revision Notes: Edexcel A-level History: Germany, 1871-1990: united, divided and reunited|date=2017|publisher=Hodder Education|isbn=9781471876653|url=https://books.google.it/books?id=UUo_DQAAQBAJ&pg=PT22&lpg=PT22&dq=%22national+liberals%22+protectionism+bismarck&source=bl&ots=QtOHZbTyiO&sig=n16Uv7oUubm8kiqRPz-_x6nD5fE&hl=it&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjzrb6W7PTUAhVOLFAKHaeUCZsQ6AEIXDAH#v=onepage&q=%22national%20liberals%22%20protectionism%20bismarck&f=false|accessdate=20 July 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Flynn|first1=John F.|title=At the Threshold of Dissolution: The National Liberals and Bismarck 1877/1878|jstor=2639216|journal=The Historical Journal|date=1988}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://countrystudies.us/germany/31.htm |title=Germany - The Tariff Agreement of 1879 |website=Countrystudies.us |accessdate=2017-07-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://countrystudies.us/germany/31.htm |title=Germany - The Tariff Agreement of 1879 |publisher=Countrystudies.us |date= |accessdate=2017-07-20}}</ref> Additionally, the NLP (which had obtained around 30% in the first three federal elections, including 30.1% in the [[German federal election, 1871|1871 federal election]]) suffered huge losses in the [[German federal election, 1878|1878 federal election]] and especially the [[German federal election, 1881|1881 federal election]] (when it was reduced to 14.6%). Later, the party experienced a steady decline in its share of vote, contextually with the rise of the [[Social Democratic Party of Germany|Social Democratic Party]] and the [[Centre Party (Germany)|Centre Party]] at the turn of the century.
During the [[Weimar Republic]], the NLP was succeeded by the [[German People's Party]] (DVP), whose main leader was [[Gustav Stresemann]], Chancellor (1923) and Minister of Foreign Affairs (1923–1929). The DVP, which was joined by some moderate elements of the [[Free Conservative Party]] (FKP) and the [[Economic Union (political party)|Economic Union]] (WV),<ref name=VM>Vincent E McHale (1983) ''Political parties of Europe'', Greenwood Press, p421 {{ISBN|0-313-23804-9}}</ref> was generally thought to represent the interests of the great German industrialists and has been classified as a national-liberal party by several observers.<ref>{{Citation |first=Jürgen |last=Dittberner |title=Sozialer Liberalismus: Ein Plädoyer |publisher=Logos |year=2008 |pages=55, 58}}</ref><ref>{{Citation |first=Wolfgang (ed.) |last=Neugebauer |title=Handbuch der Preussischen Geschichte |volume=3 |publisher=de Gruyter |year=2000 |page=221}}</ref><ref>{{Citation |first=Liesbeth |last=Van De Grift |title=Securing the Communist State: The Reconstruction of Coercive Institutions in the Soviet Zone of Germany and Romania, 1944-48 |publisher=Lexington Books |year=2012 |page=41}}</ref> Its platform stressed Christian family values, secular education, lower tariffs, opposition to welfare spending and agrarian subsidies and hostility to "[[Marxism]]" (that is to say, both the [[Communist Party of Germany|Communist Party]] and the Social Democratic Party). After Stresemann's death, the DVP, whose ranks included several anti-republicans, veered sharply to the right.<ref>{{cite book|last=Evans|first=Richard J.|authorlink=Richard J. Evans|title=[[The Third Reich Trilogy#The Coming of the Third Reich|The Coming of the Third Reich]]|publisher=[[Penguin Group|Penguin Press]]|location=[[New York City]]|date=2003|isbn=978-0141009759}}</ref>
The current [[Free Democratic Party (Germany)|Free Democratic Party]] (FDP), which was the joint successor of the DVP and the [[social liberalism|social liberal]] [[German Democratic Party]] (DDP), originally featured conservative and partly nationalist efforts, which were particularly strong in some state associations until the 1950s<ref>Gert-Joachim Glaeßner: Politik in Deutschland, VS Verlag für Sozialwissenschaften 2006, p. 457</ref> and more occasionally after that (an interesting example is that of [[Jürgen Möllemann]], FDP leader in [[North Rhine-Westphalia]] in 1983–1994 and 1996–2002)<ref>http://www.untag-smd.ac.id/files/Perpustakaan_Digital_2/POLITICS%20AND%20GOVERNMENT%20The%20Politics%20of%20the%20Nazi%20Past%20in%20Germany%20and%20Austria.pdf</ref> and still includes a national-liberal faction,<ref>{{cite book |title=Liberal Parties in Western Europe |last=Kirchner |first=Emil Joseph |year=1988 |publisher=Cambridge |location=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-0-521-32394-9 |page=214 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9IrE08SV1wEC |accessdate= }}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> which holds a consistently [[Euroscepticism|Eurosceptic]] position, differently from the rest of the party.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Taggart |first1=Paul |last2=Szczerbiak |first2=Aleks |title=The Party Politics of Euroscepticism in EU Member and Candidate States |series=SEI Working Paper |volume=51 |page=11 |publisher=Sussex European Institute |doi= |url=http://www.sussex.ac.uk/sei/documents/wp51.pdf |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091210232136/http://www.sussex.ac.uk/sei/documents/wp51.pdf |archivedate=10 December 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Some right-wing elements, including Sven Tritschler (former leader of the Stresemann Club),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://rechtsliberale.wordpress.com/personen |title=Wir | Stresemann Club - Rechtsliberale in der FDP |website=Rechtsliberale.wordpress.com |date=2012-04-20 |accessdate=2017-07-20}}</ref> have more recently joined the [[Alternative for Germany]] (AfD),<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www1.wdr.de/fernsehen/westpol/sendungen/afd-nrw-steckbriefe-100.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-05-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304235510/http://www1.wdr.de/fernsehen/westpol/sendungen/afd-nrw-steckbriefe-100.html |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> which has in turn been characterised by some observers as national liberal.<ref name="Franzmann2015">{{cite book|author=Simon Franzmann|editor1=Gabriele D'Ottavio|editor2=Thomas Saalfeld|title=Germany After the 2013 Elections: Breaking the Mould of Post-Unification Politics?|chapter=The Failed Struggle for Office Instead of Votes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_mLBCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA166|year=2015|publisher=Ashgate|isbn=978-1-4724-4439-4|pages=166–167}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.freitag.de/autoren/idefix/die-populistische-versuchung |title=AfD ǀ Die populistische Versuchung — der Freitag |language=de|publisher=Freitag.de |date=2009-11-20 |accessdate=2017-07-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tagesschau.de/inland/patzelt-sachsen-landtagswahl-100.html |title=Politologe analysiert Landtagswahl: "Den Sachsen geht es zu gut" |website=tagesschau.de |date=2014-09-01 |accessdate=2017-07-20}}</ref>
===Austria=== In [[Austria-Hungary]], the [[Constitutional Party (Austria)|Constitutional Party]] was the main representative of national liberalism.<ref name="Mulej"/> In [[Austria]], national liberalism has remained the basis of one of the three ''Lager'', or ideological camps, in the country, dating back to the [[Revolutions of 1848 in the Austrian Empire]].<ref>{{Cite book |title=The new politics of the Right: neo-Populist parties and movements in established democracies |editor1-first=Hans-Georg |editor1-last=Betz |editor2-first=Stefan |editor2-last=Immerfall |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H9cGkDJgW7wC&lpg=PP1&hl=no&pg=PA27#v=onepage&q&f=false |year=1998 |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |isbn=978-0-312-21338-1 |chapter=The Freedom Party of Austria: From Protest to Radical Right Populism |first=Max |last=Riedlsperger |page=27}}</ref> During the [[interwar period]], the national-liberal camp was gathered into the [[Greater German People's Party]].<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V6DURCH53f4C&printsec=frontcover&dq=Modern+Austria#v=onepage&q&f=false |first=Barbara |last=Jelavich |title=Modern Austria: Empire and Republic, 1815-1986 |publisher= Cambridge University Press |year=1987 |page=168}}</ref> By 1938, with the ''[[Anschluss]]'' of Austria into [[Nazi Germany]], the national-liberal camp had been swallowed whole by [[Austrian National Socialism]] and all other parties were eventually absorbed into Nazi totalitarianism.<ref name="R28">{{Cite book |title=The new politics of the Right: neo-Populist parties and movements in established democracies |editor1-first=Hans-Georg |editor1-last=Betz |editor2-first=Stefan |editor2-last=Immerfall |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H9cGkDJgW7wC&lpg=PP1&hl=no&pg=PA27#v=onepage&q&f=false |year=1998 |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |isbn=978-0-312-21338-1 |chapter=The Freedom Party of Austria: From Protest to Radical Right Populism |first=Max |last=Riedlsperger |page=28}}</ref> Both Socialists and Christian Socials were persecuted under the Nazi regime and the national-liberal camp was scarred after the war due to [[association fallacy|guilt by association]] with National Socialism.<ref name="R28"/>
In 1949, the [[Federation of Independents]] (VdU) was founded as a national-liberal alternative to the main Austrian parties.<ref name="M186">{{Cite book |format=PhD thesis |url=http://vbn.aau.dk/files/20049801/spirit_phd_series_25.pdf |last=Meret |first=Susi |year=2010 |title=The Danish People’s Party, the Italian Northern League and the Austrian Freedom Party in a Comparative Perspective: Party Ideology and Electoral Support |series=SPIRIT PhD Series |publisher=[[University of Aalborg]] |volume=25 |issn=1903-7783|page=186}}</ref> It incorporated an array of political movements, including free market liberals, populists, former Nazis and German nationalists, all of whom had been unable to join either of the two main parties.<ref name="M186"/><ref>{{cite book|title=The politics of exclusion: debating migration in Austria|last1=Krzyżanowski|first1=Michał|last2=Wodak|first2=Ruth|year=2009|page=36|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V3qXaV9EYREC&dq=|publisher=Transaction|isbn=978-1-4128-0836-1}}</ref><ref name=cb>{{cite book|title=World fascism: a historical encyclopedia|volume=1|last=Blamires|first=Cypriam|year=2006|page=70|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nvD2rZSVau4C&dq|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-57607-940-9}}</ref> The VdU evolved into the [[Freedom Party of Austria]] (FPÖ) in 1955–1956.<ref>{{cite book|title=Constitutional law of 15 EU member states|first1=L. |last1=Prakke|first2=C. A. J. M.|last2=Kortmann|first3=J. C. E.|last3=van den Brandhof|year=2004|page=42|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b5vZMPbnNXcC&dq|publisher=Kluwer|isbn=978-90-13-01255-2}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Die Geschichte der Freiheitlichen|last=Piringer|first=Kurt|year=1982|page=326|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=utYlAAAAMAAJ&q|publisher=Orac}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Österreichs Parlamentarismus: Werden und System|last=Schambeck|first=Herbert|year=1986|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z8MlAAAAMAAJ&q|publisher=Duncker & Humblot|isbn=978-3-428-06098-6}}</ref> When [[Jörg Haider]] was chosen as new FPÖ leader in 1986, the party started an ideological turn towards [[right-wing populism]], which resulted in the split of most liberals, who formed the [[Liberal Forum]] (LiF), which took over the FPÖ's membership in the [[Liberal International]] and would later eventually merge into [[NEOS – The New Austria and Liberal Forum|NEOS]]. Haider himself would split from the party and form the [[Alliance for the Future of Austria]] in 2005.
===Denmark=== In [[Denmark]], from the 1840s the core concept of national liberalism was that the nation and the state should have the same extent. National liberals supported the union the Kingdom of Denmark and the [[Duchy of Schleswig]] under a common constitutional framework. On the economy, the state should not interfere with trade and the national-liberal economic vision was transposed in the 1857 Law on Freedom of Business, which abolished the last remnants of the feudal monopolies which had previously formed the framework for the craft of the cities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.danmarkshistorien.dk/leksikon-og-kilder/vis/materiale/nationalliberalisme |title=Nationalliberalisme |website=Danmarkshistorien.dk |publisher=Aarhus Universitet |accessdate=2017-07-20}}</ref> Danish national liberals supported [[Scandinavism]] and thus Scandinavian unity.<ref name="Hilson">{{cite book|author=Mary Hilson|chapter=Denmark, Norway, and Sweden|editor1=Timothy Baycroft|editor2=Mark Hewitson|title=What Is a Nation?: Europe 1789-1914|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iLYUDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA203|year= 2006|publisher=OUP Oxford|isbn=978-0-19-929575-3|page=203}}</ref>
===Sweden=== In [[Sweden]], in the 1860s liberals described themselves as national liberals (''nationalliberaler'') and constituted a coalition of monarchists and liberal reformists in support of parliamentary reforms.<ref name=Kuunmaki/>{{verification needed|date=May 2017}} Swedish national liberals also supported Scandinavism.<ref name="Hilson"/>
===Finland=== In the [[Grand Duchy of Finland]], an [[autonomous entity|autonomous]] part of the [[Russian Empire]], where as many as 80% of the population was Protestant and Finnish-speaking, somewhat under 20% Protestant Swedish speakers (Sweden ruled Finland until 1809) and a small number Russian Orthodox, the term "national liberal" was used by the elite Swedish-speakers of the [[Svecoman movement]] who advocated liberal ideals, but wanted to keep Swedish as the dominant language, an idea opposed by Finnish-speaking nationalists of the [[Fennoman movement]].<ref name=Kuunmaki/>{{verification needed|date=May 2017}} The Svecoman movement gave birth to the Swedish Party, which was later renamed [[Swedish People's Party in Finland]], which has since moved to mainstream liberalism and [[social liberalism]] and is often a party of government in the country.
===Russia=== In [[Russia]], "national liberalism" was a 1990s movement claiming to be redefining "liberal" principles as understood in the Western tradition to produce a "national liberalism" better suited to Russian culture,<ref name="EvansEdinburghCompanion">{{cite book|last1=Evans|first1=Mark|title=The Edinburgh Companion to Contemporary Liberalism|date=2001|publisher=PsychologyPress|isbn=1579583393|page=273}}</ref> being practically a variety of [[Russian nationalism]].
Presidential candidate in [[Russian presidential election, 2018|2018 presidential election]], [[Ksenia Sobchak]] of [[Civic Initiative]], considers herself a national liberal.
===Romania=== In [[Romania]], the [[National Liberal Party (Romania)|National Liberal Party]] (PNL), founded in 1875, revived in 1990 and enlarged in 2014 (when it absorbed the [[Democratic Liberal Party (Romania)|Democratic Liberal Party]], PDL), has also been part of the national-liberal tradition. Today, it is one of the country's two main parties. President [[Klaus Iohannis]] hails from it. The PNL is now mainly [[Liberal conservatism|liberal-conservative]] and [[Pro-Europeanism|pro-Europeanist]] placed on the [[Centre-right politics|centre-right]] of the [[political spectrum]] concerning economy, society, culture, freedom of expression and civil liberties.
===Slovakia=== [[Freedom and Solidarity]] (SaS), the [[Liberalism|liberal]]<ref>http://www.parties-and-elections.eu/slovakia.html</ref> and [[libertarianism|libertarian]]<ref>[https://books.google.it/books?id=yctgCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT726&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false Routledge Handbook of European Elections] edited by Donatella M. Viola, Google Books.</ref> main opposition party after the [[Slovak parliamentary election, 2016|2016 parliamentary election]] in [[Slovakia]], has been shifting from liberalism to [[Euroscepticism]] and [[nationalism]] and/or combining liberalism and nationalism. As a fact, SaS is not a member of the [[Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Party]], but of the [[Alliance of Conservatives and Reformists in Europe]], along with conservative and Eurosceptic parties. SaS leader [[Richard Sulík]] described himself both as a liberal and as a nationalist,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=|title=Richard Sulík: Áno, som slovenský nacionalista|url=https://dennikn.sk/688253/richard-sulik-sas-som-slovensky-nacionalista-rozhovor/|journal=Dennik N|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> but later corrected himself by saying that he was a liberal and a [[patriotism|patriot]] while condemning [[chauvinism]], [[racism]] and [[religious fanaticism]] and opposing the withdrawal of Slovakia from the [[European Union]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://dennikn.sk/690096/som-slovensky-liberal/|title=Som slovenský liberál|last=Sulík|first=Richard|work=Denník N|access-date=2017-10-16|language=sk-SK}}</ref> However, the party has never been classified as national-liberal by third-party sources.
===Czech Republic=== In [[Austria-Hungary]] the [[Young Czech Party]], emerged in 1874 after a split from the [[Old Czech Party]], was a national-liberal force. During [[Czechoslovakia]]'s era (1918–1992), a few parties were described as national-liberal: [[Czechoslovak National Democracy]], the [[National Labour Party (1925)|National Labour Party]] and, after 1989, the [[Czech National Social Party]].
Today, the conservative [[Civic Democratic Party (Czech Republic)|Civic Democratic Party]] (ODS) in the [[Czech Republic]] has been described as a national-liberal party.<ref name="NaglePerspective">{{cite book|last1=Nagle|first1=John|title=Democracy and Democratization: Post-Communist Europe in Comparative Perspective|date=1999|publisher=SAGE|isbn=0761956794|page=193|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RLRuXV9vjswC&pg=PA193&dq=%22national+liberalism%22++rights+democratic&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi2vIHM5PbTAhWG6yYKHYADCyMQ6AEIMzAD#v=onepage&q=%22national%20liberalism%22%20%20rights%20democratic&f=false|accessdate=17 May 2017}}</ref> The ODS is a member of the [[Alliance of Conservatives and Reformists in Europe]], as [[Slovakia]]'s [[Freedom and Solidarity]], and the [[International Democrat Union]].
==Other uses== Several political parties have included "national liberal" in their names or ideology. A list is available at [[National Liberal Party (disambiguation)|National Liberal Party]].
